expert.name: Andrew Huberman
expert.bio: Stanford neuroscientist and host of the Huberman Lab podcast. Known for science-backed protocols on sleep, focus, and performance.

supplements.name: L-Theanine
supplements.description: Amino acid from tea that promotes calm focus and improves sleep quality

supplements.name: Magnesium Threonate
supplements.description: Highly bioavailable form of magnesium that crosses blood-brain barrier for cognitive and sleep support

supplements.name: Apigenin
supplements.description: Flavonoid from chamomile that promotes relaxation and sleep

supplements.name: Glycine
supplements.description: Amino acid that lowers core body temperature and improves sleep quality

supplements.name: Alpha-GPC
supplements.description: Choline source that enhances focus, memory, and athletic performance

supplements.name: L-Tyrosine
supplements.description: Amino acid precursor to dopamine and norepinephrine for focus and motivation

supplements.name: Phenylethylamine (PEA)
supplements.description: Trace amine that enhances mood and focus

supplements.name: Rhodiola Rosea
supplements.description: Adaptogenic herb that reduces fatigue and enhances stress resilience

supplements.name: Tongkat Ali
supplements.description: Herbal extract supporting testosterone and reducing cortisol

supplements.name: Fadogia Agrestis
supplements.description: Herbal extract that may support luteinizing hormone and testosterone

supplements.name: Ashwagandha
supplements.description: Adaptogenic herb that reduces cortisol and anxiety while supporting testosterone

supplements.name: Inositol
supplements.description: B-vitamin-like compound that supports mood and sleep when taken in high doses

supplements.name: Acetyl-L-Carnitine (ALCAR)
supplements.description: Amino acid derivative supporting mitochondrial function and cognitive performance

interventions.name: Morning Sunlight Exposure
interventions.description: View bright sunlight within 30-60 minutes of waking for 10-30 minutes (depending on cloud cover). Do not wear sunglasses. Sets circadian rhythm and cortisol pulse.

interventions.name: Cold Exposure
interventions.description: Cold shower or ice bath at 45-55Â°F for 1-3 minutes. Creates sustained dopamine increase of 250-300% lasting 3+ hours.

interventions.name: Deliberate Cold Exposure Protocol
interventions.description: 11 minutes total cold exposure per week, divided into 2-4 sessions. Water temp should be uncomfortable but safe.

interventions.name: Non-Sleep Deep Rest (NSDR)
interventions.description: Yoga Nidra or NSDR protocol: 10-30 minutes of guided relaxation to restore dopamine and reduce fatigue

interventions.name: Physiological Sigh
interventions.description: Double inhale through nose followed by long exhale through mouth. Fastest way to reduce stress in real-time.

interventions.name: 90-Minute Focus Blocks
interventions.description: Work in 90-minute ultradian cycles matching natural brain rhythms. Take breaks between blocks.

protocols.name: Huberman Sleep Stack
protocols.description: Supplement stack for improved sleep onset, depth, and architecture. Take 30-60 minutes before bed.

supplements.name: Magnesium Threonate
supplements.rationale: Crosses BBB for cognitive and sleep benefits

conditions.notes: Skip if vivid dreams are unwanted

supplements.name: Glycine
supplements.rationale: Lowers core body temperature for sleep onset

interventions.rationale: Sets circadian rhythm for proper melatonin release at night

protocols.description: Supplement and behavioral stack for enhanced focus and cognitive performance during work blocks.

protocols.description: Tools for managing acute and chronic stress through breathing, supplements, and NSDR.

interventions.name: Non-Sleep Deep Rest (NSDR)
interventions.rationale: Restores dopamine and reduces accumulated stress

nutrition_principles.guidance: Delay first meal 2-3 hours after waking to extend morning focus and fat oxidation. Stay hydrated with water, salt, and caffeine if desired.
Delay caffeine 90-120 minutes after waking to avoid afternoon crash. Clear adenosine naturally first.
For morning workouts, fasted training is fine. For afternoon, eat a light meal 2-3 hours before.
Save larger carbohydrate portions for evening to support serotonin production and sleep.
Include 2-4 servings of fermented foods daily (kimchi, sauerkraut, kefir) for gut microbiome diversity.
